replies.bodyText: we have already a relative-to attribute. Having a path that is relative to relative-to (right?) seems a bit too much IMO.
replies.author: pruivo

replies.bodyText:
Every single other reference to a file in our config uses the path/relative-to pair. Remember that relative-to is not a path directly but the name of a property. This mimics the behaviour of WildFly where, for each file in the config, the relative-to attribute is set to the appropriate default (e.g. infinispan.server.config.path or infinispan.server.data.path) without having to include it in the path attribute directly (e.g. ${infinispan.server.config.path}/credentials.pfx).
We could remove all traces of relative-to: if a path is relative, it will be relative to the default path for that element.

Maybe I've got things mixed up. The example in the doc shows bin/cli.sh credentials add dbpassword -p "secret1234!" where -p is the keystore password.
The alias of "dbpassword" is not equivalent to a username. It is the alias of the credential in the keystore.
I think the example needs to be bin/cli.sh credentials add dbpassword -c mysupersecretcredential -p "secret1234!"
However, when using a default property realm, I still don't see how to map the alias of the credential to a username. Is that possible?

replies.bodyText: AFAIK, it is only for "service" passwords, like DB access, LDAP access, decrypt Keystore (SSL). It was never intended for users' accounts.
